metadata.title: Plant Identification Guesses
metadata.description: Speculative plant identifications based on visual features, assuming 15th century European (likely Italian) origin
metadata.confidence_scale: LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH - based on distinctiveness of features

f38r.reasoning: Single large lobed leaf with white stem is unusual. The white comma-shaped markings could represent spots or stylized venation. Arum species have single large leaves and were common in medieval herbals. The white/pale stem and prominent root also fit Arum.
f38r.medieval_use: Arum was used medicinally (though toxic). Comfrey for wound healing.
f38r.notes: The white markings are very distinctive - may be artistic convention rather than botanical accuracy

f9v.reasoning: Opposite oval leaves, branching woody stem, small flowers at leaf axils. Myrtle was extremely common in medieval Mediterranean gardens and herbals. The leaf shape and arrangement are consistent.
f9v.medieval_use: Myrtle: perfume, medicine, sacred plant. Symbol of love and immortality.
f9v.notes: Very typical herbal-style depiction of a shrubby plant
